summary: A company is a separate legal entity distinct from its members. Even a one-man company has a separate existence from its sole shareholder.
description: Aron Salomon was a leather merchant and boot manufacturer who incorporated his business as a limited company, with himself and family members as shareholders. When the company went into liquidation, the question arose whether Salomon could be held personally liable for the company's debts. The House of Lords unanimously held that the company was a separate legal entity from Salomon, and he was not liable for its debts beyond his shareholding. This established the foundational principle that a company, once incorporated, is a separate person in law distinct from its members.
key_points: A company is a legal person separate from its members
Limited liability protects shareholders from company debts
The corporate veil can only be lifted in exceptional circumstances
One-man companies are valid legal entities
Creditors of the company cannot sue shareholders personally

case_name: Tata Consultancy Services v. State of AP
summary: Computer software on medium is goods liable to sales tax.
description: The case examined whether software supplied on a medium (CD, floppy disk) constitutes 'goods' for the purpose of sales tax. TCS argued that software is intellectual property and not goods. The Supreme Court held that software, when put on a medium and sold, becomes tangible property and qualifies as 'goods' under the Sales Tax Act. The court distinguished between customized software (service) and canned/packaged software (goods).
key_points: Canned/packaged software on a medium is considered 'goods'
Software has the attributes of movable property
Distinction between customized software (service) and canned software (goods)
Sales tax is applicable on sale of packaged software
Intellectual property can become goods when embodied in a physical medium

case_name: Kesavananda Bharati v. State of Kerala
summary: Parliament can amend the Constitution but cannot alter its basic structure. The basic structure includes supremacy of the Constitution, rule of law, separation of powers, and fundamental rights.
relevance: Most important constitutional law case in India
description: This is the most consequential constitutional case in Indian legal history. A 13-judge bench of the Supreme Court, in a 7-6 majority, held that while Parliament has the power to amend any provision of the Constitution under Article 368, it cannot alter or destroy the 'basic structure' or framework of the Constitution. This doctrine has since been the cornerstone of Indian constitutional law, preventing any government from fundamentally altering the democratic character of the Constitution through amendments.
key_points: Parliament can amend the Constitution under Article 368 but cannot destroy its basic structure
Basic structure includes: supremacy of the Constitution, republican and democratic form of government, secular character, separation of powers, federal character
Fundamental rights form part of the basic structure
Judicial review is part of the basic structure
The doctrine was decided by a 7-6 majority of a 13-judge bench
Overruled the earlier Golaknath case partially
related_sections: Constitution of India - Part III (Fundamental Rights)

case_name: Maneka Gandhi v. Union of India
principle: Right to Life and Personal Liberty
summary: Article 21 does not merely guarantee the right against deprivation of life or personal liberty but also the right to live with dignity. Any procedure depriving a person of life or liberty must be just, fair, and reasonable.
description: Maneka Gandhi's passport was impounded by the government without giving her any reason or opportunity of being heard. The Supreme Court held that the right to 'life' in Article 21 is not merely confined to animal existence but includes the right to live with human dignity. The procedure established by law must be right, just, and fair, and not arbitrary, fanciful, or oppressive. This case transformed Article 21 into the most significant fundamental right, from which many other rights have been derived.
key_points: Right to life under Article 21 includes right to live with dignity
Procedure established by law must be just, fair, and reasonable (not arbitrary)
Articles 14, 19, and 21 are interconnected — a law must satisfy all three
Right to travel abroad is part of personal liberty under Article 21
Principles of natural justice are implicit in Article 21
Overruled the narrow interpretation from A.K. Gopalan case

summary: The Supreme Court laid down guidelines to prevent sexual harassment of women at the workplace. These guidelines were binding until the enactment of the Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace Act, 2013.
description: This PIL was filed by women's rights groups after the brutal gang rape of Bhanwari Devi, a social worker in Rajasthan who tried to prevent child marriage. In the absence of any legislation addressing sexual harassment at the workplace, the Supreme Court framed the 'Vishaka Guidelines' which defined sexual harassment, placed obligations on employers, and mandated the creation of complaints committees. These guidelines had the force of law until Parliament enacted the Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace (Prevention, Prohibition and Redressal) Act, 2013.
key_points: Defined sexual harassment at workplace comprehensively for the first time
Made it the duty of employers to prevent sexual harassment
Mandated creation of Complaints Committees in every workplace
Guidelines were binding as law until POSH Act 2013 was enacted
Used international conventions (CEDAW) to fill legislative gaps
Extended protection to both public and private sector

case_name: Navtej Singh Johar v. Union of India
summary: Section 377 of IPC was struck down to the extent it criminalized consensual sexual conduct between adults. The court held it violated Articles 14, 15, 19, and 21 of the Constitution.
description: A five-judge Constitution Bench unanimously struck down the colonial-era Section 377 of the Indian Penal Code insofar as it criminalized consensual sexual acts between adults in private. The court overruled the 2013 Suresh Kumar Koushal judgment that had reinstated Section 377. Each judge wrote a separate but concurring opinion, emphasizing that sexual orientation is an intrinsic part of identity and that the LGBTQ community is entitled to equal citizenship and protection of fundamental rights.
key_points: Section 377 IPC partially struck down (consensual adult sexual conduct decriminalized)
Sexual orientation is an intrinsic part of identity protected under Article 21
LGBTQ persons are entitled to full constitutional protection
Overruled Suresh Kumar Koushal v. NAZ Foundation (2013)
Discrimination based on sexual orientation violates Article 15
Constitutional morality prevails over social morality

case_name: K.S. Puttaswamy v. Union of India
summary: Right to privacy is a fundamental right under Article 21 of the Constitution. It includes informational privacy, bodily autonomy, and the privacy of personal choices.
relevance: Foundation for data protection law in India
description: A nine-judge Constitution Bench unanimously held that the right to privacy is a constitutionally protected fundamental right under Articles 14, 19, and 21. The judgment arose in the context of challenges to the Aadhaar scheme. The court overruled the earlier M.P. Sharma (1954) and Kharak Singh (1962) judgments that had denied privacy as a fundamental right. Justice Chandrachud's opinion emphasized that privacy is essential to human dignity and personal autonomy.
key_points: Right to privacy is a fundamental right under Article 21
Privacy includes informational privacy, bodily autonomy, decisional autonomy, and privacy of personal choices
Overruled M.P. Sharma (1954) and Kharak Singh (1962) on this point
Any restriction on privacy must satisfy the threefold test: legality, legitimate aim, proportionality
Privacy is not an absolute right and can be subject to reasonable restrictions
Foundation for India's data protection legislation

case_name: Shreya Singhal v. Union of India
summary: Section 66A of the IT Act was struck down as unconstitutional for being vague and overbroad, violating the right to freedom of speech and expression under Article 19(1)(a).
relevance: Key internet freedom and free speech case
description: Section 66A of the Information Technology Act, 2000 made it a criminal offence to send 'offensive' messages through a computer or communication device. The Supreme Court struck down this provision, holding that terms like 'annoying', 'inconvenience', and 'grossly offensive' were vague and undefined, leading to a chilling effect on free speech. The court also read down Section 79 (intermediary liability) to require a court order before content could be taken down.
key_points: Section 66A IT Act struck down as unconstitutional for vagueness
The provision had a chilling effect on free speech under Article 19(1)(a)
Terms like 'annoying' and 'grossly offensive' are too vague for criminal law
Section 79 (intermediary liability) read down to require court orders for takedowns
Distinguished between discussion, advocacy, and incitement
Online speech enjoys the same constitutional protection as offline speech

case_name: M.C. Mehta v. Union of India
summary: An enterprise engaged in a hazardous or inherently dangerous activity owes an absolute duty to the community to ensure no harm. No exceptions or defences are available — stricter than the Rylands v. Fletcher rule.
relevance: Foundation of environmental law in India
description: Following the Oleum gas leak from Shriram Industries in Delhi, M.C. Mehta filed a PIL seeking closure of the factory and compensation for victims. The Supreme Court evolved the principle of 'absolute liability', going beyond the English rule of strict liability from Rylands v. Fletcher. Under this doctrine, an enterprise carrying on a hazardous or inherently dangerous activity is absolutely liable for any harm caused, regardless of whether it exercised due diligence. No exceptions like act of God, act of a stranger, or consent of the plaintiff are available.
key_points: Doctrine of absolute liability — no defences or exceptions available
Stricter than strict liability under Rylands v. Fletcher
Applies to enterprises engaged in hazardous or inherently dangerous activities
Compensation must be proportional to the magnitude and capacity of the enterprise
Polluter pays principle recognized
Foundation of Indian environmental jurisprudence

case_name: S.R. Bommai v. Union of India
summary: The imposition of President's Rule under Article 356 is subject to judicial review. Secularism is a basic feature of the Constitution. The court restricted misuse of Article 356 by the central government.
description: Multiple state governments were dismissed by the Centre using Article 356, leading to this challenge. A nine-judge bench held that the proclamation of President's Rule is subject to judicial review and cannot be used for political purposes. The court held that secularism is a basic feature of the Constitution and a state government pursuing anti-secular policies can be legitimately dismissed. The judgment established important safeguards against the arbitrary use of Article 356.
key_points: President's Rule under Article 356 is subject to judicial review
Article 356 cannot be used for political purposes by the Centre
Secularism is a basic feature of the Constitution
The material relied upon by the President must be made available to the court
If the proclamation is found unconstitutional, the court can restore the dissolved government
Federal structure is part of the basic structure of the Constitution

case_name: Olga Tellis v. Bombay Municipal Corporation
summary: The right to livelihood is included in the right to life under Article 21. Pavement dwellers cannot be evicted without following due process of law and providing them a hearing.
relevance: Expanded Article 21 to include right to livelihood
description: Pavement and slum dwellers in Bombay challenged their eviction orders. The Supreme Court held that the right to livelihood is an integral part of the right to life under Article 21, since no person can live without the means of living. While the court recognized that the dwellers were occupying public property illegally, it held that they could not be evicted without being given a hearing and reasonable notice. The government was directed to provide alternative sites or transit accommodation.
key_points: Right to livelihood is part of right to life under Article 21
Eviction of pavement dwellers without due process is unconstitutional
No person can live without the means of living — livelihood is essential
Government must provide reasonable notice before eviction
Alternative accommodation should be provided where possible
Even illegal occupants are entitled to procedural fairness

case_name: Indian Young Lawyers Association v. State of Kerala
summary: The ban on entry of women aged 10-50 into Sabarimala temple was held to be violative of their fundamental rights under Articles 14, 15, 25, and 26 of the Constitution.
description: The Indian Young Lawyers Association challenged Rule 3(b) of the Kerala Hindu Places of Public Worship (Authorization of Entry) Rules, 1965, which prohibited women between the ages of 10 and 50 from entering the Sabarimala temple. In a 4:1 majority, the Supreme Court struck down the rule, holding that the exclusion of women based on a biological factor (menstruation) amounted to discrimination. Justice Indu Malhotra dissented, arguing that courts should not interfere with essential religious practices. The case was later referred to a larger bench for reconsideration.
key_points: Ban on women (10-50) entering Sabarimala struck down by 4:1 majority
Exclusion based on menstruation is discriminatory under Article 15
Women have equal right to worship under Article 25
Devotees of Lord Ayyappa do not constitute a separate religious denomination under Article 26
Justice Indu Malhotra's dissent — courts should not interfere with religious practices
Case referred to larger 7-judge bench for reconsideration

case_name: Arnesh Kumar v. State of Bihar
summary: Police must not automatically arrest the accused in cases under Section 498A IPC. Magistrates must not mechanically authorize detention. Laid down specific guidelines to prevent misuse of arrest powers.
description: The case arose from the rampant misuse of Section 498A IPC (cruelty by husband or his relatives), where arrests were being made mechanically without proper investigation. The Supreme Court laid down mandatory guidelines requiring police officers to satisfy themselves about the necessity of arrest based on specific parameters under Section 41 CrPC. Magistrates were directed not to authorize detention casually. Non-compliance was made a ground for departmental action against the police officer and contempt of court proceedings.
key_points: Arrest under Section 498A IPC should not be automatic or routine
Police must follow checklist under Section 41(1)(b)(ii) CrPC before arrest
Magistrate must record reasons for authorizing detention
Non-compliance results in departmental action and contempt proceedings
Applies to all cases where punishment is up to 7 years imprisonment
Aimed at preventing misuse of anti-dowry laws

case_name: Lalita Kumari v. Government of UP
summary: Registration of FIR under Section 154 CrPC is mandatory if the information discloses commission of a cognizable offence. Police cannot refuse to register an FIR.
relevance: Ensures access to criminal justice system
description: Lalita Kumari's minor daughter was abducted, and the police refused to register an FIR. A five-judge Constitution Bench held that registration of FIR under Section 154 CrPC is mandatory when information received by the police discloses the commission of a cognizable offence. The police officer cannot conduct a preliminary inquiry before registering the FIR in cases involving cognizable offences. However, in cases where the information does not clearly disclose a cognizable offence, a preliminary inquiry may be conducted within 7 days.
key_points: FIR registration is mandatory upon receiving information about a cognizable offence
Police cannot refuse to register an FIR — it is a statutory duty
Preliminary inquiry allowed only in exceptional cases (within 7 days)
Non-registration of FIR is punishable under Section 166A IPC
A copy of the FIR must be given to the informant free of cost
All FIRs must be uploaded on a police website within 24 hours

case_name: Shayara Bano v. Union of India
summary: The practice of instant triple talaq (talaq-e-biddat) was declared unconstitutional. It violated the fundamental rights of Muslim women under Articles 14, 15, and 21.
relevance: Led to Muslim Women (Protection of Rights on Marriage) Act, 2019
description: Shayara Bano challenged the practice of instant triple talaq (talaq-e-biddat) after her husband divorced her by uttering talaq three times. A five-judge Constitution Bench, in a 3:2 majority, struck down the practice. The majority held that triple talaq is not an essential religious practice protected under Article 25 and is manifestly arbitrary, violating Article 14. This judgment led to the enactment of the Muslim Women (Protection of Rights on Marriage) Act, 2019, which criminalized instant triple talaq.
key_points: Instant triple talaq (talaq-e-biddat) declared unconstitutional by 3:2 majority
Triple talaq is not an essential religious practice under Article 25
The practice is manifestly arbitrary and violates Article 14
Muslim women have equal right to dignity and non-discrimination
Led to the Muslim Women (Protection of Rights on Marriage) Act, 2019
Parliament was directed to legislate on the matter within 6 months
related_sections: Muslim Women (Protection of Rights on Marriage) Act 2019
